data.title: Joseph Cousselle and Louisa Langley, Marriage License, 1853

headnote.content: A marriage license then and now is fairly straightforward: it is a record of a couple’s legal relationship. But it also contains pertinent chronological, demographic, and social information about the couple and their families.

question.content:
1) What is a cordwainer?
2) What evidence is there of a class difference in the parents’ occupations?

data.title: Ship’s Passenger List, American Eagle, 1853
data.source_caption: Records of the U.S. Customs Service, Record Group 36; National Archives, Washington, D.C.

headnote.content: Like a marriage license, a ship’s passenger list is also fairly obvious: it is a record of people going from one place to another. But it also contains occupational, geographic, and political information. The ship American Eagle made regular trips between New York and England in the 1850s. Its primary business was transporting passengers traveling to and from New York and London. Most of these passengers were, however, northern Europeans, primarily from England and Germany, emigrating to the United States.

question.content:
1) Who are the Cousselles’ fellow travelers in terms of social class?
2) How long after their marriage did the Cousselles emigrate to the United States?
3) What does this document list as Louisa Cousselle’s citizenship? Why?

data.title: Internal Revenue Service, Nevada Tax List, Nevada, 1865

headnote.content: Passed in 1862 to raise money for the Union cause during the Civil War, the Internal Revenue Act placed a tax on various goods and services. All persons, partnerships, firms, associations, and corporations, according to the legislation, submitted to a local federal assessor a list showing the amount of annual income, articles subject to special taxes and duties, and the quantity of goods made or sold that were liable to taxes or duties. While there is much we cannot learn from a tax list, it can provide clues as to where a person was living and what his or her relative wealth was in comparison with other members of the community.

question.content:
1) What did Louisa Cousselle pay tax on?
2) In what ways did her taxable property conform (or not) to nineteenth-century gender expectations?
3) Where does Louisa Cousselle fit, in terms of taxes paid, in comparison to her neighbors?

data.title: Fire Losses, 1874, Helena, Lewis & Clark County, Montana
data.creditline_caption: Subscription History, "Fire Losses, 1874, Helena, Lewis & Clark County, Montana."
data.source_caption: Michael Leeson, "Lewis and Clarke County," History of Montana, 1739–1885 (Chicago: Warner, Beers & Company, 1885): 717–718.

headnote.content: Many western towns were liable to fires for a host of reasons, and Helena was no exception; it suffered devastating fires in 1869, 1871, and 1874. Taken from a subscription history, the partial list enumerates resident losses in the fire.

question.content:
1) How many individual men and how many individual women suffered losses?
2) What was the average individual loss in the fire? How did Cousselle’s loss compare with the average loss? What might this comparison suggest about her financial standing?
3) Why might Cousselle have moved to Bozeman?

data.title: U.S. Manuscript Census, 1880, Gallatin County, Bozeman
data.creditline_caption: U.S. Manuscript Census, 1880, Bozeman, Gallatin County, Montana Territory.
data.source_caption: Tenth Census of the United States, 1880.

headnote.content: The Census Bureau instructed enumerators to collect the following information for each household: address (name of the street; house number), occupants (name of each person and their relationship to head of family), sex, race, age, marital status, ability to read and write, birthplace, birthplace of parents, occupation (trade or profession; number of months unemployed), health (whether blind, deaf and dumb, crippled, maimed, idiotic, insane, bedridden, or otherwise disabled), number of months unemployed during the year; and the state or country of birth of every individual’s father and mother.

question.content:
1) Why did Louisa Cousselle move to Bozeman?
2) What was her occupation?
3) Does the data from the 1880 census change your interpretation of data from earlier documents?

data.title: Louisa Cousselle, Will & Probate, 1883 & 1886 (excerpt)
data.description: Part of a much larger document set, Louisa Cousselle’s will and probate details an array of family relationships and her intention regarding the disposition of her real and chattel property.
data.creditline_caption: Probate Court, Gallatin County, Bozeman, Montana Territory.

headnote.content: Part of a much larger document set, Louisa Cousselle’s will and probate details an array of family relationships and her intention regarding the disposition of her real and chattel property.

question.content:
1) What were the most surprising revelations contained in the will?
2) What do these surprises suggest about Cousselle’s life?
3) What do Louisa Cousselle’s bequests suggest about her values?
4) Why is Louisa Cousselle’s will and probate so important?

data.title: "Death of Mrs. Lou," Avant Courier [Bozeman, Montana Territory], June 26, 1886

headnote.content: Obituaries were (and are) summaries of an individual life. Death notices of notable and notorious individuals also provided some insight into the community’s view of the departed as well as the community’s values.

question.content:
1) What parts of the obituary confirm evidence from the other sources?
2) What was the writer’s and, by extension, the community’s view of Louisa Cousselle?
3) What did the reporter apparently value when he evaluated Cousselle’s life?

data.title: Louisa Cousselle’s Gravestone, Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York
data.creditline_caption: Headstone, Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York, 2009 (photo by Paula Petrik).

headnote.content: In the nineteenth century it “counted” to be buried in Brooklyn’s Greenwood Cemetery. As one observer wrote, “It is the ambition of the New Yorker to live upon the Fifth Avenue, to take his airings in the Park, and to sleep with his fathers in Green-Wood.” Among those buried in Greenwood were Horace Greeley, who once advised young men to go west, and Lola Montez, a noted exotic dancer and courtesan.

question.content:
1) Why did Cousselle choose Greenwood Cemetery as her final resting place?
2) What does her choice suggest about her aspirations?

data.title: Tax List, Helena, Lewis & Clark County, Montana, 1867
data.creditline_caption: Subscription History, Tax List 1867, Helena, Lewis & Clark County, Montana.
data.source_caption: Michael Leeson, "Lewis and Clarke County," History of Montana, 1739–1885 (Chicago: Warner, Beers & Company, 1885): 681–682; 685–686.

headnote.content: Property taxes were the mainstay of local western governments and provide an index into an individual’s economic position. Although this list is only a partial tabulation, it can be used as a rough sample for the whole.

question.content:
1) How many individual men and how many individuals held property?
2) What was the average individual assessed property value?
3) How did Cousselle’s property value compare with the average property value?

data.title: U.S. Census Bureau, Census List for Helena, Lewis & Clark County, Montana Territory, 1870
data.creditline_caption: U.S. Manuscript Census, 1870, Helena, Lewis & Clark County, Montana Territory.

headnote.content: The Census Bureau instructed enumerators to record the names of every person in the household. Tallies included the following categories in the census: name; age at last birthday (if a child was under one year of age, months of age were to be stated as fractions, such as 1/12); sex; color; profession; occupation or trade of every male and female; value of real estate; place of birth; whether mother and father were of foreign birth; whether born or married within the year and the month; those who could not read; those who could not write; whether deaf, dumb, blind, or insane or "idiotic." No relationships were shown between members of a household.

question.content:
1) Is Louisa Cousselle listed on the page? How do you know?
2) If she is listed, what information does she give the census taker? Evaluate its accuracy and account for any discrepancies.

data.title: "Montana Mention," Daily Yellowstone Journal (Miles City, Montana), March 6, 1886
data.creditline_caption: Daily Yellowstone Journal (Miles City, Montana), March 6, 1886.

headnote.content: The Yellowstone Journal was the paper of record for Miles City, a cattle trans-shipment point in the eastern part of Montana, some 288 miles from Bozeman.

question.content:
1) What does the incident described in the Yellowstone Journal add to an account of Cousselle’s financial dealings?
2) Why would a newspaper publish an account of an event involving two demimonde residents in a town nearly 300 miles away?

data.title: 300 Block Carlton Avenue, Brooklyn, New York, 2009
data.creditline_caption: Cityscape, Carlton Avenue Block, Brooklyn, New York, 2009 (photo by Paula Petrik).

headnote.content: Although Louisa Cousselle’s house no longer stands, the row house neighborhood in Brooklyn’s Park Slope area looks much the same as it did in 1880s when Louisa Cousselle built her brick house sometime after 1881.

question.content:
1) By its physical appearance, what kind of neighborhood does Carlton Avenue appear to be?
2) What does the Carlton Avenue neighborhood suggest about Cousselle’s life in Brooklyn?
